body.p:
I received with great pleasure your letter
of the 25th Novr and can assure you that I esteemed
it an honor to receive a communication from one so well known by
his literary reputation both in America & England

I can assure you that my business during the
months of December & January occupies so much of my time
that I am precluded from attending to any private mat
ters, and the letter which I received from my brother in
Cincinatti by the mail which brought me your favor
was only answered last week. This explanation will I
hope be considered by you satisfactory, and an
ample apology for not replying to you ere this.

I think it better to have to state openly to you the
reason why I cannot undertake to percure subscribers
for your Bible, than to lead you to believe that I am
either unwilling or too lazy to attempt to do so. You
are aware that Dr. Berusch who is in intimate terms
with me announced some time ago his intention
of publishing a translation of the Bible, and when it
was intended to form a committee for the purpose of
aiding him pecuniarily in the task I acted as the
Honorary Secretary of the same. That plan being abandon
ed & the doctor undertaking the task in his own respon-
sibility I lent him my assistance in procuring subscribers
and the first part of the work viz the Pentateuch is already
in the hands of 600? subscribers I need not tell you
that a person on the spot has a great advantage over
one living at a distance. D. B has announced his inten

intention of continuing the work and I may add that
the same is ? at this ? by the permission
of the marrying committee, Dr. Berusch having been for
many years connected with the society. As Secretary
of the Institution & as a friend of the doctor, and
having already interested myself for the success of
the work, you will perceive that it would not
be possible for me to canvass for subscribers to your
Bible, and if I were to do so, you must be aware
that the English Jews would give the preference
to a work published here, as doubtless the Americans
would do & have done to one printed in the
United States. I do not consider that Mrs. ?
makes a good agent for the Occident my brother
writes that you informed him that Mr Franklin
had led you to expect great assistance from him
in the circulation of the work, but I may say
that as he was unable to make his own paper
succeed it ought not to surprise you that he
was unable or perhaps to procure a ? favorable
reception for another editors work. I will endeavour
to procure you some subscribers for the occident
but the Jews here do not like subscribing to
foreign Journals and when the L'Ouivers? was
first published I could only procure for him
? 2 subscribers & he has only 6 in London.

Yours however being written in our native tongue
ought to meet with a better reception, but as
the Jews subscribe to the Jewish Chronicle which
they like (at least many of them,) altho there are
many opinions on the merit of the paper as a
literary organ, they are not eager to subscribe

for another. I must express my surprise that in the
United States occupied by so many Jews you can
not find supporters enough, for the "Chronicle is
supported here altho many are very dissatisfied
with it.

I cannot say who was the person who corres-
ponded for your paper under the signature of O.
I have been often asked whether I was the
writer & can assure you that I was not.

To reply to your request that I should write a
monthly letter for your Journal in the state of
Jewish affairs in England, I will undertake
the task with pleasure if you think I can be
of any service to you. I should wish to remain
incrg—for I do not like as I am holding public
offices to write under my name as I might feel
my opinions obacstled if therefore you wish
me to do as you have requested a letter in reply
to this shall have in return my first letter to
the occident which I will sign Hebrew that being
my name in hebrew.

Should you ever intend paying us a visit in
this, thinking that a personal interview with our
co-religionists in this city, would lend to give a
larger circulation to your periodical I shall be
most happy to see you & render you every assistance
in my power
